description: Middle English, from Latin dimissus (“sent away, dismissed, banished”), perfect passive participle of dīmittō (“send away, dismiss”), from dis- +‎ mittere (“to send”).

verbs.description: dismiss (third-person singular simple present dismisses, present participle dismissing, simple past and past participle dismissed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To discharge; to end the employment or service of.
examples: The company dismissed me after less than a year.
The soldiers were dismissed after the parade.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To dispel; to rid one’s mind of.
examples: He dismissed all thoughts of acting again.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To reject; to refuse to accept.
(transitive) To invalidate; to treat as unworthy of serious consideration.
examples: By telling the victim to "get over it", the listener dismissed the victim's feelings.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To send or put away, to discard with disregard, contempt or disdain. (sometimes followed by as).
examples: She dismissed him with a wave of the hand.

entries.meaning: (transitive, cricket) To get a batsman out.
(transitive, soccer) To give someone a red card; to send off.
